prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information
Defences Raised as a Result of the Plaintiff's Inaction

para.paratext: As stated earlier, there is no statute as yet pertaining specifically to confidential information. However, where an action is brought in Ontario for simple contract or tort, s. 45(l)(g) of the Limitations Act[1] governs. In addition, where a claim is not expressly covered by a statutory limitation period but is similar to one of the causes of action listed, the relevant limitation period is applied by way of analogy.[2] An action for breach of confidential information would, provided it is based in contract, fit within s. 45(l)(g), and as such, after the stipulated six-year limitation period, a plaintiff would be precluded from instituting a claim for breach of confidential business information.
